subject: Add GET method for Triggers
commitMessage:
Add GET method for Triggers

Added GET method for retrieving details of individual Trigger searched
by given Trigger name, details are extracted from Telemetry service

Tested:
- Added single Trigger and requested result from bmcweb via
  /redfish/v1/TelemetryService/Triggers/<triggername>
- Added multiple Triggers numeric and discrete with various parameters
  (empty, non-empty), and requested results from bmcweb via
  /redfish/v1/TelemetryService/Triggers/<triggername>
- Verified uris /redfish/v1/TelemetryService/Triggers/<triggername> by
  using Redfish-Service-Validator (all passed)

Signed-off-by: Lukasz Kazmierczak <lukasz.kazmierczak@intel.com>
Change-Id: I1c966b2f792324cc6f6a8784ad18a683e5ce7bd9

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1b7e696bb97d12125117f71c9d710cd482a54c85 by Ed Tanous
Make sure that comments are aligned to 72 characters, don't break line too early.
Done
As far as I know you should avoid using auto in bmcweb.
Done by removing all autos in scope of my modification, except those used within structured bindings.
What does this Ext mean?

This is used to avoid conflict with implementation of POST method for Triggers. For POST there is TriggerThresholdParams variant defined without monostate as dbus call for AddTrigger doesnt accept monostate alternative in the variant. But still for GET Trigger part, monostate can be used within variant and that's why separate alias is Ext suffixed here.
No additional comments here, so closing this one. Please reopen if the matter still requires additional discussion.
Use find instead to avoid .at which throws exception.
There is no chance to throw 'out of range' exception, due to key existence is checked by params.count(key), but even though I will try to use find here instead.
Version without possible throw should produce smaller binary: https://godbolt.org/z/bxTvKxaja
Also if you look at the assembler you can notice that even if this no way to throw there is still code with call to throw (it's not executed, but it's there).
Done
You can't move const&
Ack
This should be placed when all possible errors are handled. We don't want to include this along with internalError message.
Ack

The code you have included in the comment represents the old way of extracting data from the variant. I have suggested something new which in my opinion is more compact, easier to read and robust. If you do not mind I would wait for comments from the others and if after all restoring the old method will be confirmed as a must here I will sadly comply.

There is existing solution which could be used:
https://github.com/openbmc/sdbusplus/blob/master/example/get-all-properties.cpp

In this example throwing version of unpackProperties is used, recently there was added non throwing version and you could use it instead if you want to propose something more compact.

After seeing how bmcweb is maintained I would like to suggest something that in my opinion has changes of being accepted.

There need to be separate commit which doesn't introduce new functionality it just changes old usage with new usage in couple of places. Once it gets positive feedback all other usages in whole bmcweb needs to be replaced with new approach (As far I understand currently in bmcweb that's the only way to change existing style to new one). As an addition binary size needs to be measure before and after this change.
Done
Let's keep this open and see what maintainers think about it.

I like to see new patterns that consolidate code, while not having an impact on binary size (or improving it).

Specifically in this case, I want to make sure that:
1. When new parameters are added to an interface, we can support both the new and old interfaces for a period of time.
2. the binary size and performance are identical to as if this code were written out naively.
3. The code is readable by someone not familiar with the inner workings of dbus.
4. bmcweb is as consistent as we can make it, such that when people look for examples while writing new code, they find good, consistent uses of the dbus bindings.
5. We're not doing things inefficiently on dbus (ie, calling Get 4 times instead of GetAll once).


So long as getAllProperties meets those, I'm happy to have it, I just don't like seeing it mixed in with a new handler, as it doesn't prove that it's capable of #1, hard to measure #2, and could cause problems with #3 if not followed through.  Changing an existing handler to use this new pattern is better because:

We can use a non-trivial handler (ie one that already has to support #1)
We can directly measure the binary impact when using it.
We can directly compare new code, with old code, including error handling, which helper functions might ignore/abstract away.
We should use "Name" property from dbus here.
Done

Please follow the existing patterns we have for reading in dbus properties when building new resources.  If these patterns are something you'd like to see as a new coding style:

1. It definitely doesn't belong in a trigger specific file.
2. It should be done separately from enabling a new resource type, such that we can evaluate its effect on binary size and code duplication.
Done
This is constructing yet another map, and forcing a significant amount of code to be generated which is slower than the way we handle this in other places.
Done
Please use if/else if ladders like we do elsewhere.  They compile to smaller code, use less memory, and are faster.
Done
if this fails we should be setting internalError
Done

Please prefer to return early which saves scopes.

Also, when this fails, we need to set internal error (500) per DEVELOPING.md
Done
This is a perfect case of where we shouldn't be using auto.  from this context, it's impossible to know the type of name, severity, dwellTime, or value, without jumping between references.

I would vote to keep this structured binding as it is here, I understand its drawbacks, which I will keep in mind in the future, however this C++ feature is commonly used in bmcweb especially in 'for' loops and IMO this code is much easier to read than i.e. using a tie instead.
toDurationString can fail.  Please handle the failure.
Done
std::chrono::milliseconds is signed, dwelltime is unsigned, which can lead to over/underflow.  Please handle that case.
Done

as written, this is going to do a map lookup 3 times for the same key.  Please use brace initialization to reduce this to one lookup.

Something like:

thresholds[type] = {{"Reading", reading}, {"Activation", activation}.... ect
Done
Same comments as above are present in this function as well.
Done

similar to above, please prefer to return early, and handle your error with 500 internalerror when this check fails.  There are several more of these in this file, but this is that last time I'll add a comment for it.  Please fix all of them.
Done
If you don't need to take ownership (as this function doesn't) there's no need to pass by shared_ptr.  Pass by crow::Response&.
Used passing of 'asyncResp->res.jsonValue' instead, gives the same effect to what you had suggested.
Given that id can be customer generated, doesn't this need url escaped.  Ie, if I create an ID that has a space in it, this will break.

Trigger Id is initially stored in Telemetry Service which does Id name validation of acceptable characters that can only be in scope of [a-zA-Z0-9_] and additionally Id must be unique across Trigger collections. So i.e. trying to create trigger with Id name having a space in it will give you error, trying to get trigger by Id with space in Id name will give you ResourceNotFound error as such name cannot exist in Telemetry.

> Trigger Id is initially stored in Telemetry Service which does Id name validation of acceptable characters that can only be in scope of [a-zA-Z0-9_] and additionally Id must be unique across Trigger collections. So i.e. trying to create trigger with Id name having a space in it will give you error, trying to get trigger by Id with space in Id name will give you ResourceNotFound error as such name cannot exist in Telemetry.

Sure, but at a bmcweb level, we can't guarantee that, because the dbus interfaces don't enforce it.  With that said, it's wrong in a lot of other places, so we can just fix it when https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/48297/3 lands.
I understand your remark, I suggest to go on with the change as it is now and upgrade it once your improvement is submitted. Is this approach acceptable?
Looks duplicated with line 212?  Generally we don't take Names from dbus, given they're part of the API boundary.
Duplication removed, Trigger Name is initially stored in Telemetry Service which handles the Name in accordance with the Redfish Specification, it can be safely used here.

Please use sdbusplus::message::path::operator+= for this operation.  The only place we use this pattern anymore is for things that had different escaping rules that had yet to be updated (ie sensors).
Done

Just FYI, at some point I'm going to start advocating for using a common variant type to avoid code duplication:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/49657

Doesn't need fixed in this commit, but just be aware it's coming.
This should go in time utils, not in trigger.hpp  Please also write some unit tests for it.
Done
Done

Last I understood, this still compiled much larger than doing a simple loop.  Do we understand why yet?  This isn't a pattern I want to propogate if it causes large binary sizes.

Also, from a maintenance standpoint, it doesn't have the ability to support optional parameters on an interface, nor multiple interfaces, nor type conversion at the callsite, so I worry a little bit about its usefulness as written as interfaces adjust over time.  If this is a pattern you'd like to see, lets move over one of the previously written (ideally a non-trivial) handlers to it first to determine its utility and impact on binary size.  Using new patterns on new code is difficult to maintain, as it can cause maintenance issues where it isn't clear if our design pattern is incorrect, or this specific handler is incorrect.  Also, I worry a little bit about having two patterns for this;  Is this a pattern you're willing to propagate through the codebase?

Due to your doubts regarding usage of 'unpackPropertiesNoThrow' I decided to use accepted and common in bmcweb approach for extracting properties. And so I am closing this one as done, but please let us raise the subject of including 'unpackPropertiesNoThrow' into bmcweb later on in a separate discussion.
Great, sounds good to me.

This looks wrong to me.  from the redfish spec"This type shall specify the condition, in relationship to the discrete trigger values, which constitutes a trigger."

Whether or not the discrete triggers list is empty doesn't really determine that, does it?  Am I missing something?

As stated in DMTF (https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Triggers.v1_2_0.json) the DiscreteTriggers shall be present when DiscreteTriggerCondition is 'Specified', when DiscreteTriggers is empty then we assume that DiscreteTriggerCondition represents 'Changed'.

This behavior is reflected just like this in Telemetry Service - in there if at least one discrete threshold is defined for the Trigger then appropriate actions are executed exactly when value from related metric meets given threshold condition ('Specified' state), on the other hand when no discrete thresholds are defined for the Trigger appropriate actions are executed every time when value from related metric is changed ('Changed' state).

Therefore at this point checking discreteTriggers against being empty is sufficient to deduce state of DiscreteTriggerCondition.
ACK.  Explanation seems reasonable,
